title: AAQ: Why Is Lust Still Strong Even After Deep Spiritual Progress? | HG Suvyakta Narasimha Dasa
speaker: HG Suvyakta Narasimha Dasa

segments.key_quote: Krishna describes kama or lust as nitya vairinaha. It is an eternal existence. It is the eternal enemy of a transcendentalist, of a person who wants to practice spiritual life.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the question of why lust persists even after spiritual progress, explaining that Krishna describes lust (kama) as an eternal enemy to spiritual practitioners.

segments.key_quote: As long as we do not give up the mode of passion, as long as we do not situate ourselves in sattoguna, the mode of goodness, what will happen, we will not be able to become free from the influence of lust and anger.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the interconnectedness of lust, anger, greed, illusion, envy, and madness, explaining that they arise from the mode of passion (rajoguna) and can only be overcome by cultivating the mode of goodness (sattoguna).

segments.key_quote: If I pursue material knowledge, I want to do engineering, I want to do medical... All that material education we acquire in the schools and colleges are actually increasing the rajoguna component of rajoguna in our life.
segments.summary: The speaker asserts that freedom from lust requires ceasing association with the mode of passion, which is prominent in the material world and increased by the pursuit of material knowledge.

segments.key_quote: Pursuit of material education in schools and colleges, as well as what we learn from the society around us, both of them are actually teaching us to increase the amount of Rajoguna in our lives. Then how can you become free from this one, lust?
segments.summary: The speaker explains that both formal material education and the knowledge acquired from society contribute to increasing the mode of passion, thus intensifying lust.

segments.key_quote: In the Vedic times, the emphasis was not on material education. The emphasis was on spiritual education... so when that spiritual knowledge was most prominent in people's lives the influence of lust was also less
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts modern society's material advancement with the Vedic emphasis on spiritual education, arguing that the former leads to increased lust while the latter fostered restraint.

segments.key_quote: The more materially advanced you are the lesser the control on lust the greater the display of lust so if we associate with the mode of passion the greater the display of lust
segments.summary: The speaker argues that despite perceived advancements in civility and equality, material progress correlates with a decline in control over lust and an increase in its manifestation.

segments.key_quote: If you want to become free from lust you have to increase the component of and if you have to increase whatever is aspired for in the modern day society you have to give up...In Kali Yuga, the method is to directly associate with Krishna himself.
segments.summary: The speaker states that overcoming lust requires increasing sattva guna, which in Kali Yuga is best achieved by directly associating with Krishna through devotional practices.

segments.key_quote: Even great sages like Vishwamitra Muni, even he, such a great sage, even he fell victim to lust. So therefore, unless we increase the component of Bhakti in our life, unless we ensure that we remain connected with Krishna... we cannot help but be conquered by the forces of lust and anger.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the difficulty of conquering lust, even for great sages, and stresses the need for constant connection with Krishna through bhakti to avoid being overcome by lust and anger, using the story of Vishwamitra Muni as an example.

segments.key_quote: We have to fill our life constantly from every moment, eating, sleeping, waking, every moment, whatever we are doing, we have to keep remembering Krishna... Chant Hare Krishna, Hare Krishna, Krishna Krishna, Hare Hare, Hare Rama, Hare Rama, Rama Rama, Hare Hare.
segments.summary: The speaker advises filling every moment with remembrance of Krishna, particularly through chanting the Hare Krishna mantra, to prevent the entry of maya and lust.

segments.key_quote: Krishna Surya Sama, Krishna is like Surya. One Krishna is enough, brilliant like the sun. Maya Hoi Andhaka and Maya, material energy, is like the darkness of the night... Prabhupada created this movement, the International Society for Krishna Consciousness... to give us this opportunity to learn, to get trained, how to remain always in remembrance of Krishna and to never forget him.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the analogy of Krishna as the sun and maya as darkness to illustrate that the presence of Krishna dispels maya, and emphasizes that ISKCON was created to train individuals to constantly remember Krishna.

segments.key_quote: In a simple way, if you have to get free from lust, only way is to develop devotional service to Krishna. And that also won't happen overnight. It takes several years of practice and it requires lot of training... You have to do lot of hard work. You have to show your sincerity to Krishna that yes, you want to become free from lust.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes that overcoming lust requires developing devotional service to Krishna through sustained practice, training, and sincere effort, emphasizing that there are no shortcuts.
